Approaching the target 38 The Financial Scorecard was applied There is a general change to the baseline and a limited change compared to the past year but some of the objective of the project will be achieved In particular Legal regulatory and institutional frameworks are in a good level The level of Business planning and tools for costeffective management is poor The level will increase as the ANAC Financial Plan is concluded the ANAC Business Plan is in progress and two other consultancies on revenue generationcanalization mechanisms will be finalized until this year In addition ANAC is currently developing the regulations for the recently approved Conservation Law All this tools will improve the legal and the institutional frameworks as well as the operational activities in the ANAC and PAs system The score of Tools for revenue generation by PA system will also increase for the same reasons

Adaptive capacity of coastal communities improved and coastal zone resilience to climate change enhanced.
1. % of targeted population affirming ownership of adaptation processes (disaggregated by gender)
2. % change in income generation in targeted area given existing and projected climate change.
3. % of population with access to improved flood and drought management, disaggregated by gender.

comment.narrative:
National data and information relevant to coastal erosion and climate change risk management is currently very limited. Some climatic records focusing on a few weather parameters are held in government departments, but detailed records of more complex variables such as stream flow and sediment transport which can help development of a more robust CC risk profile of coastal zones are few in number.
Lack of data and poor management of physical coastal data presents a barrier to adequate monitoring and forecasting of the impacts of climate change on coastal zones. Responsibility for development and implementation of coastal land use planning legislation and relevant regulatory frameworks is also fragmented and duplicated across different sectors and government departments. Existing laws often are not applied or enforced. Decision-makers at national, sub-national and at local level are not informed and trained to extract/use environmental data and information, particularly that related to SLR and coastal erosion, to adjust municipal land use regulations and investment planning for CC coastal risk management. Access to mass media and other IT communication systems in rural areas is low, and illiteracy rates are high which pose a challenge to the dissemination of climate risk information. Average illiteracy level in Mozambique is about 56.7%, but much higher among women (71.2%). Furthermore, the most illiterate people live in the rural areas (INE, 2009). OUTCOME 1
OUTCOME 2: Baseline: Historical records from 1960-2005 point to a warming trend, particularly in central and north Mozambique of 1.1-1.6 ºC in maximum temperatures which can be significantly higher for the lowland coastal areas. In addition the analysis of these past records also indicates significant increases in duration of heat waves, as well as a delay in the start of the rainfall season. Furthermore to this, maximum temperatures are expected to increase by 2.5-3.0 ºC in the interior by 2040-2060.
Coas

50% of men and women in the selected project sites have declared ownership of adaptation processes.
50% of households in the pilot sites have increased their income by 50% (cumulative).
50% of households have improved flood and drought management (cumulative).

Target Achieved. Overall, 1,205 direct beneficiaries were involved in different project activities in the three pilot project sites (7 communities), and indirectly benefited 380 from the provision of temporary services such as procurement of local materials and labor for construction of some identified adaptation measures. Thus 1,585 individuals of which 54% women and 46% men is the total number of beneficiaries from adaptation measures.
Target Partially Achieved. Over 70% targeted beneficiaries benefited from Micro-finance services and products, mainly in Pemba and Sihane. Micro-finance failed in Pebane due to constraints with the Service Provider. Diverse livelihoods options were developed and still active in the 2 sites.
Target Partially Achieved. Flood protection implemented effectively in Pemba. Being finalized drainage system in Paquite community. Coastal erosion mapping exercise finalized, pending validation.
Project Final Evaluation and Closure.

comment.narrative:
The VCA consultations during the PPG phase have shown that though aware of their vulnerability and that of the surrounding ecosystem farmers fishermen and all those whose livelihoods are affected by CC induced hazards at the district and community level have no financial resources and knowledge for resilience decision making in the face of droughts and floods
The coastal management expert report revealed that there is currently no protection measures being undertaken by communities against sea level rise and storm surges

At the end of the project 50 of men and women in the selected project sites have declared ownership of adaptation processes disaggregated by gender
By the end of the project 50 of households in the pilot sites have increased their income by 50
50 of households have improved flood and drought management

Adaptation measures have been validated and prioritized at the community level and technical partners increasing ownership of adaptation process Community investment plans have been prepared submitted and approved by the Investment committee Access to finance and training Inhambane 5 demonstration fields in place SDAE working with same number of 1215 members group with 98 women 1 womens group 5 People trained and equipped for chicken production and received inkind loan chicks and food from FDM hired microfinance service provider for this project site 1 womens group organized and trained for swine production and building pigpen FDM This represents innovative production technology into low productivity agricultural and breeding practices For the other two project sites Cabo Delgado and Zambezia no activity reported for community training Microfinance institutions have been hired and started to work in all communities In Inharime Inhambane province FDM was contracted Diagnostic study realized Staff trained in saving and credit group methodology and 1 staff hired to work full time in Sihane community 6 savings and credit groups trained and active saved 64115 Mts 2 groups being prepared for inkind loans for chicken amp swine production All participants SCG Production groups receiving business training and financial education In Pemba Cabo Delgado province CCOM was contracted To date 20 credit officers were trained to work in the 3 communities and in their production areas out of town 3 service centers have been established A specialized institution hired by MFI to train its staff in the savings and credit group methodology Training ongoing with first groups to be formed by the end of July 2015 14 solidarity groups received loan 70 people for MZN 45500000 33 individuals loans provided 6 Women 18 for MZN 136 Million Total value of loans MZN 1815 Million of which 26500000 already paid back 5 ind 1 group All loans for small business petty trade that will description.narrative: Climate change risks to coastal zones integrated into key decisionmaking process and managed at community level as well as subnational and national government level
1 Capacity Perception Index

comment.narrative:
Capacity Assessment score 2455
The project will improve the capacity of local Govt to i to engage in stakeholder dialogue to understand needs and priorites for CCA ii the capacity to develop a climate risk problem analysis and create a vision and mandate for CCA initiatives iii to formulate policy and strategy on CCA initiatives 4 the capacity to budget manage and implement CCA initiatives
The scorecard uses 10 indicators deemed by stakeholders to be the most important capacity gaps
Capacity Assessment score 3835

Continued support has been provided to key government institutions at the subnational level in integration of CCA initiatives in their planning cycle These included key partnerships with the National Disaster Management Institute Municipality of Pemba District Authorities of Pebane and Inharrime National Meteorological Institute Agricultural Research Institute the Center for Sustainable Development Higher School of Marine Sciences Eduardo Mondlane University Marine Administration and the recently established Climate Change Knowledge Center at the Academy of Science of Mozambique Initial training in GIS and GPS usage and data collection have been undertaken in the three project sites Pemba Pebane and Zavora for development of CC risk mapsprofiles to further inform the planning system Climate information systems have been improved since project inception to support incorporation of CC risks into decisionmaking and planning

Target Partially Achieved. 132 members of the local communities are employed in reforestation activities and community development initiatives.
Target achieved. From July 2015 to June 2016 only 20 fires larger than 100 ha were registered, which comprises 8,650 ha. These findings were based on statistics compiled using remote sensing data that are publicly available. The product is called MCD45A1. This is a monthly Level-3 gridded 500-meter product, which contains burning and quality information on a per-pixel basis. Each pixel of 500 m x 500 m is therefore 25 hectares in extent. Produced from both the Terra and Aqua MODIS-derived daily surface reflectance inputs, the algorithm analyses the daily surface reflectance dynamics to locate rapid changes. It uses that information to detect the approximate date of burning, and maps only the spatial extent of recent fires. The MCD45 product was downloaded for the period July 2015 till May 2016. No processed data are yet available for June 2016. However, raw data are available on the daily occurrence (but not the extent) of active fires. No active fires were recorded by the satellite above 700 m for the month of June 2016.
Target Partially Achieved. Additional 9 community-based rangers employed by GRP.

description.narrative: Objective Strengthen the overall effectiveness and sustainability of Mozambiques Protected Area System including financial sustainability through working partnerships between public private NGO and community stakeholders
1 Financial sustainability scorecard for national system of protected areas

comment.narrative: greater than 45

Approaching the target 38 The Financial Scorecard was applied There is a general change to the baseline and a limited change compared to the past year but some of the objective of the project will be achieved In particular Legal regulatory and institutional frameworks are in a good level The level of Business planning and tools for costeffective management is poor The level will increase as the ANAC Financial Plan is concluded the ANAC Business Plan is in progress and two other consultancies on revenue generationcanalization mechanisms will be finalized until this year In addition ANAC is currently developing the regulations for the recently approved Conservation Law All this tools will improve the legal and the institutional frameworks as well as the operational activities in the ANAC and PAs system The score of Tools for revenue generation by PA system will also increase for the same reasons

description.narrative: 2 Capacity development indicator score for protected area system

comment.narrative:
Systemic 46
Institutional 46 Individual 35

Systemic 60
Institutional 55
Individual 50

Approaching the target Systemic 49 Institutional 49 Individual 76 There are not significant changes comparing to the baseline and only marginal progress has been made For systemic and Institutional level the activities in progress will improve the scores as there are some changes in the ANACs management structure For the individual one the critical situation in Gorongosa is in part overpassed and actually some activities useful to improve the indicators levels has been developed The results can be considered very good This fact can be considered also a success story in the biodiversity conservation policies in Mozambique With new Government after 2014 elections the management of PAs system was moved from the Ministry of Tourism MITUR to newly created Ministry of Land Environment and Rural Development MITADER This has created an added value to the PAs system as some of regulatory instruments were dependent to former Ministry for Coordination of Environmental Affairs MICOA which mandates now belongs to the same ministry MITADER

comment.narrative: Baseline and target reconstruction would be needed because adequate data on this was not available at project start Baseline and targets were established not very stringently New data is available now Yet from all indications progress is good with room for improvement A historical analysis of the NASA FIRMS data has now been completed for the main historical Park for the period 20002013 The average fire return interval is 32 years which translates to 31 of the Park being burned every year This is in line with Fire Return Intervals recorded for other large tropical savanna ecosystems such as Niassa This analysis has brought up some methodological issues which will need to be considered in the analysis of the data for the Mountain In any case is reasonable considering that the indicator level is good but can be improved

a) 250 STAE staff trained on civic education; b) 55 Disctricts have benefited from electoral civic education; c) 45 Secondary school have benefited from electoral civic education; d) 10 workshops on civic education held for Media and Political Parties, respectively; At least 30% of benefitiaries of training and awareness raising events should be Women

comment.narrative: a) STAE staff capacity in civic education to be improved in view of new approaches; b) Civic education ot be targeted mostly to the low voter turn out districts; c) MoU between EMBs and Ministry of Education currently under negotiation. Secondary school students are the potential new voters; d) Media and Political Parties are key actors in elections and need to be fully informed and capacitated on the issue; Participation of Women in electoral processes need to be improved.

- At least 150 STAE staff trained on elections matter including electoral civic education - At least 45% of participants in STAE training are women - Electoral civic education carried out in at least 30 secondary schools - 2 workshops carried out by CSOs with the participation of at least 45% of women

- Over 75 staff members of EMB trained on elections matter including electoral civic education - Workshop for the revision of the current electoral legislation carried out by EMBs with the participation of 30 secialists - Over 12,000 students from secondary schools have benefited from electoral civic education, out of which 42% were girls - A platform of 1000 focal points composed by community leaders and teachers was established to ensure permanent electoral civic education at community level in central provinces of Mozambique
initiate project closure
